option.name: title_text
option.value: ET Module 2 - Scenario - Planning for differentiation

string_table.name: npnxnanbnsnfns00001000011
string_table.string: Use the w, a, s, and d keys to move around the 360 degree image. Press the tab key to jump to interactive markers and hotspots.
To watch this video, use the preview feature in Storyline 360, upload your published output to a server, publish to Review 360, or switch to static video quality.
Streaming video is unavailable for local playback.

search.slidetext: scenarios planning for differentiation the following scenarios demonstrate three different approaches to what planning for differentiation when teaching explicitly can look like in action. to access the scenario select the begin button below, then use the arrowbuttons on the bottom of the slide to navigate the scenario. begin begin begin begin begin begin select the scenario to begin.

encourage mathew to assist peers experiencing challenges in areas where he excels, leveraging his strengths to support fellow students. provide mathew with extension tasks once he has completed the work. incorporate strategies that offer multiple entry points across each of the five stages of explicit teaching. scenarios: planning for differentiation incorporate strategies that offer multiple entry points across each of the five stages of explicit teaching. incorporate strategies that offer multiple entry points across each of the five stages of explicit teaching. incorporate strategies that offer multiple entry points across each of the five stages of explicit teaching. incorporate strategies that offer multiple entry points across each of the five stages of explicit teaching. incorporate strategies that offer multiple entry points across each of the five stages of explicit teaching. incorporate strategies that offer multiple entry points across each of the five stages of explicit teaching. provide mathew with extension tasks once he has completed the work. provide mathew with extension tasks once he has completed the work. provide mathew with extension tasks once he has completed the work. provide mathew with extension tasks once he has completed the work. provide mathew with extension tasks once he has completed the work. provide mathew with extension tasks once he has completed the work. scenario mx. s, a year 7 english teacher, recognised that their student, mathew, was considered gifted at english and mathematics and consistently performed well academically. recently, mx. s noticed that mathew was having difficulty engaging during explicit teaching lessons. mathew became more hesitant to participate and his disruptive behaviour started affecting his learning and that of his classmates. what should mx. s do to resolve this situation? select an option to explore the outcome. encourage mathew to assist peers experiencing challenges in areas where he excels, leveraging his strengths to support fellow students. incorporate strategies that offer multiple entry points across each of the five stages of explicit teaching. incorporate strategies that offer multiple entry points across each of the five stages of explicit teaching. incorporate strategies that offer multiple entry points across each of the five stages of explicit teaching. incorporate strategies that offer multiple entry points across each of the five stages of explicit teaching. encourage mathew to assist peers experiencing challenges in areas where he excels, leveraging his strengths to support fellow students. please make a selection on the response to the situation to progress page 1 | 4 select a response to continue.

context page 2 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. mx. s knows that, even though mathew has been identified as gifted, it is important that he participates in the explicit teaching lessons to ensure a good understanding of the new content being taught. scenarios: planning for differentiation

possible solution mx. s asked a colleague to come in and complete an observation during an explicit teaching sequence using an observation protocol focusing on student engagement and participation levels. in the conversation with their colleague afterwards, it became evident that while mathew was not engaging, a small number of other students were also tuning out. mx. s reflected on the students' disengagement. they hypothesised that the students were likely to be either bored or finding the learning too difficult. mx. s decided to revisit the research on explicit teaching and sought out opportunities for professional learning. they also visited the classroom of a colleague they knew who had planned and delivered effective explicit teaching lessons to a diverse cohort of students. as a result, mx. s started to incorporate strategies that offered multiple entry points across each of the five stages of explicit teaching. page 3 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. scenarios: planning for differentiation

well done! this is a good solution. select the blue x above to return to the beginning of the scenario and explore some other ways teachers might respond. or, you can return to the course. well done! overall outcome page 4 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. mx. s noticed a significant improvement in mathews focus on learning. he was more engaged and started pushing himself to extend his learning even further. this was also the outcome for other students. mx. s believed this approach positively impacted all students, as they could access the learning without mx. s needing to reduce expectations. scenarios: planning for differentiation

context page 2 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. mx. s knows how important it is for all students to understand new content and doesnt want the other students to fall behind. scenarios: planning for differentiation

possible solution page 3 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. mx. s decided to provide mathew with extension activities. they continued to plan for explicit teaching as they always had. for each lesson, mx. s also planned an extension task for mathew to complete once he had finished all other work. this involved preparing an additional activity and any associated resources. scenarios: planning for differentiation

this is not the best solution. select the blue x above to return to the beginning of the scenario and explore some other ways teachers might respond. overall outcome page 4 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. at first, mathew responded well to the added challenge of his individual tasks. he was engaged and would work through the class tasks quickly to get to the extension activities. however, after a while, mathew started to disengage again and disrupt the learning of others. mx. s also found the process of planning the extension activities time-consuming and not an effective use of their time. mx. s talked with mathew, who explained that while he enjoyed the challenge of the extension activities, he found it really boring to have to work through the other tasks first. after some reflection, mx. s decided to rethink their approach. scenarios: planning for differentiation

context page 2 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. mx. s knows that mathew is capable and recognises that some other students struggle when learning new content. scenarios: planning for differentiation

possible solution page 3 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. mx. s decided that mathew could support other students with their learning to help deepen his understanding of the content. they conversed with mathew and explained that once he had completed all tasks, he could assist other students in their learning. mathew responds positively to the idea. scenarios: planning for differentiation

this is not the best solution. select the blue x above to return to the beginning of the scenario and explore some other ways teachers might respond. overall outcome page 4 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. at first, mx. s noticed mathew made a concerted effort to complete tasks quickly and independently sought out other students to help. however, this did not last. mathew soon lost interest in helping other students, often working at levels significantly below his understanding. he again started to disengage and disrupt others' learning. mx. s realised this wasnt an effective way of supporting mathew. after some reflection, mx. s decided to rethink their approach. scenarios: planning for differentiation
